narrative: We moved down to Third and uh Wharton. We had gotten moved but it was like – you remember I told you my father drank but it was still day and after he had gotten in and put the furniture where it was supposed to go my mother left to go to market to get some food to bring into the house. And my father went to take the horses – take the team of horses back. But he didn't come home. He – uh – I stopped somewhere on – I dunno but he – that's where – how he – why he wasn't in the house. And of course I was left there with the kids. Well no sooner did my mother get out of the house – my father went first – then – oh it was such an awful crash came through the window. And I – and I looked and it was a big stone. And then of course they – they – well they stoned the house. And I had sense enough to get the kids into the stairway so that they wouldn't get hurt by flyin' gla- glass. And I said to them “Now you stay there. Don't move 'cause nothing will reach you here. And I'm gonna go and see if I can find mom” – (We call our mother mom.) And they were crying and carryin' on. I was scared to death I really was frightened out of my wits. And I didn't know what to do but I remember saying a prayer as I went out the front door because I didn't know what was gonna hit me when I went out that door. And I ran – I was ten years old at the time this happened – I ran to Fourth street because I knew my mother wa- They had push carts in those days on Fourth street. And it was a Jewish neighborhood and they – they stayed open until – until all hours. Because they would you know however much money they could get they wanted. So uh that's where she was going to do her shopping. And I finally found my mother. I did find her. And while I was trying to tell her what had happened a policeman went by. And my voice was such that you could hardly make out what I was saying. I was so nervous and – and – my voice was shaking so and he wanted to find out what ha- what was wrong with me. And then when he understood what the situation was he turned to my mother and says “This is a bad neighborhood. It's Irish.” And he said “Th- they're known to do things like that Better move out of there.” My mother said “I just moved in how am I gonna move out?” He says “I dunno.” He says “But they don't want any black people in there.” An' he didn't say black 'cause they didn't use black then. But “they don't want anybody in there.” So uh she said “Well you're the law. You're supposed to protect us.” He says “I can't do anything with it.” He was Irish himself. “I can't do anything about it.” So my mother said um “Where is the uh precinct you work from?” And he told her. I forgot now. I was right there with her but I've forgotten where he told her. So uh she said “Well if you can't do anything to help me I'll go see who – if I can't find someone else to help me.” Well in those days black people were so cowed by circumstances an' uniforms an' – an' – an' white people you know they uh many times didn't assert themselves. But thankfully my mother was not one of those kind. And uh she – well I always thought of her as an educated person which she was because she was the only one I knew who had completed high school. She went to Lackawanna uh high school. And uh this was – let me see what year was this happening – well it must have been nineteen twenty-five so you can see what – what the times were. And we went – she took me and we went to the police station. And they also had police wagons with horses attached to them. Believe it or not in those days. [break in the recording] So my mother said to the captain “What are you going to do about it?” And he says “Well lady there's nothing we can do about it.” And she says “You mean to tell me that I have to live under those circumstances and there's nothing that you can do about it?” She says – he says “Well uh uh the only thing I can tell you to do is to move.” He says “Because” – uh he said to me “Did you see anyone?” And I said “No.” He says “Well how can – how can you” – to my mother – “how can you do anything if you don't know who – who to put the blame on?” An' he says “I'm sure there was more than uh than one person.” So my mother said “Well I don't know what I'm going to do.” She says “But one thing I know I'm not going to do is move. Because I have no money to move with.” They took all we had to to pay the rent. In that house you had to pay uh in advance. And she said “If they didn't want me there they should not have rented the house to me. Now the real estate agent should be accountable.” So anyhow she said to him “Well I know one thing you can do.” And he says “What's that?” She says “You can take me home.” He said “Take you home?” She said “Yes in the police patrol.” So – I-I guess they figured “Let's get this lady out of here because she's talking loud and long.” And they had never come up with anybody like that. So they put us in the police patrol and they took us home. We weren't far from from – from where it was – maybe Fifth street – from where we had moved. And uh – course with the horses and the police patrol and the clang – they had a bell that clanged. Clang clang clang – you know they told you about the trolley that went “Clang.” Well this police patrol that bell they had it went “Clang clang clang.” And um all the neighbors came running out to see what was happening. And of course they saw the man came around the back – I can r- see it right now – from where he was sitting up front there where the horses came around and opened the door in the back. And they had a long door in the back where you had to come down steps to get out the back of the – of this police patrol. Well we got out of that police patrol – Before the patrol ever left my mother turned and faced all those people that were standing around and she says “Why you're doing this to me I don't know.” She says “I know that I am different from you color wise but in every other respect I'm just the same as you are and all I'm trying to do is provide a home for my family.” She told them that they had rented the house she told them how much money she had paid she had told them that was all the money she had. And they had paid that rent for a month. She knew she was going to be there for the month. She did not know beyond the month. Whether they'd have enough mother – money to pay it for the next month. But she knew they were going to be there for for the month. She said “It is winter time and it is cold. And I cannot afford to be buying windows.” “Now” she said “Whoever threw the stones I don't know. But you can all see what has happened. And now I'm telling you that we're going to be here for a month. So you might just as well make up your mind to that. If you don't want me here then you people get together and give me enough money to move somewhere else. because I do not have it.” Well of course you know they didn't do that. They probably didn't have any money either. So in the meantime – not in the meantime but during during the period of time that we were there my father became sick. And the neighbors were as nice as anybody could ever have been. When there was trouble they responded just like anyone else. But that was our welcoming to the neighborhood. And it was terrible and it certainly was frightening for me.

recalls.0:
The police returned the mother and boy home in the police cart with horses and a bell that went clang, clang, clang. All the neighbours came out to watch them coming home. The mum spoke to them and told them she had no money to move anywhere so they would be there for the month and maybe longer. And that she couldn't afford to keep replacing windows so they should stop breaking them and accept they were there. 
The neighbours were very nice to them and when their dad got sick were helpful.
recalls.1: They dropped them off in a police patrol which was a horse and cart and had steps. The mother came down and told the people why were they doing this to them, they were different colourwise but same otherwise. She was just providing for her family and she was going to be here for a month. The money had been spent on the rent which was due in advance They were dropped off at fourth street. The dad had been ill.
recalls.2:
The police wagon was driven by horses and made a loud clanging sound. On arriving home the neighbours heard all the clanging and came outside to see what was happening. The mother and the boy descended the steps at the back of the police wagon. The mother confronted the neighbours and said that they could not afford new windows. Look at what they had did and they had paid rent for a month and would be staying here for at least a month. The mother told the neighbours that if they were not welcome here and wanted them to move, then they should collect the money between them to raise the rent for them to move to a new house. The mother and boy entered the house.
In the near future the father fell ill and neighbours were very supportive and kind to the family.
recalls.3: The police returned the mother and the boy home in their police patrol car. When they arrived there were horses and wagons and people still there. The mother stated that she wanted to find out who threw the stone through the window as it was winter and cold and she could not afford a window, nor her rent. She said the person who threw the stone should own up or pay for her and her family to move out so that they were not there anymore. There was a discussion withe the policeman regarding colour of skin and race. The father came back and he was sick.
recalls.4: A crowd was gathered and the mother explained that she had paid a month's rent and only that. She said it was cold and she didnt have enough money to pay for the windows and indeed may not have enough money for the next months rent. She said if the crowd wanted to pay the rent she would move out but nobody offered. During the month the father got sick but the neighbours treated him well
recalls.5: The mother and boy got out of the police cart.the neighbours were all out watching. Mother said look what your all doing, I won't be leaving in the next month as can't afford it if you want me gone you give me the money. I'm different in colour but nothing else. They stayed the month. The father got ill and the neighbours were helpful.
recalls.6: The mother described how much she paid in rent for the month, her desire to simply provide a home for her family, and her lack of certainty as to whether she would have the money to pay for rent beyond the first month.  She also described that their home lacked a window.
recalls.7: they returned the mother and boy home. The mother then went on a speech, telling the local crowd that had formed all about the reality of their situation. They had no money to move, didn't understand why the locals were treating them so badly and if they really wanted them gone then they would have to find the money for her to rent elsewhere. Then a little time passes, the father becomes ill but the community is actually supportive, surprisingly after how they were treated. Seems to show that once you aren't treated as an outsider, you become an insider, regardless of colour/race etc
recalls.8: Now the real estate agent should be accountable. "So anyhow, she said to him, well i know one thing you can do".So they put us in the police patrol and they took us home. We were not far from - from where it was - maybe Fifth street -"Clang" Well this police patrol that bell they had, it went "Clang clang clang." And um all the neighbors came running out to see what was happening.- I can see it right now - from where he was sitting up in front there where the horses came around, and open the door in the back. And they had a long door in the back where you had to come down steps to get out the back of the - of this police patrol. We we got out of that police-Before the patrol ever left my mother turned and faced all those people that were standing around, and she says, "Why you're doing this to me". She says "I know that I am different from you, color wise, it in every other respect I am just the same as you are, and all I'm trying to do is provide a home. "She told them that they had rented the house, she told them how much money she had paid, she had told them that was all the money she had. Whether the had have enough money to pay for it next month. but she knew they were going to be there for a month. She said, it is winter time
recalls.9: The mother said she doesn't have enough money to move, or pay for new windows because it is winter. And if the locals want her to move so badly they should group together and provide her with enough money to move somewhere else. She told them that even though her skin may be a different colour she is just trying to provide for her family like them. The son then finishes with that was what happened when they moved in and it was "terrible".
recalls.10: The mother confronted the neighbours, telling them that she paid rent for the month. That was all she had. She was not moving. If they want her to move, then they have to pay her to move. That didn't happen. The husband was sick. The neighbours were nice to them after awhile.
recalls.11: the mother faced the crowd of Irish neighbours that had come to see what the noise was about and she addressed them, explaining that she moved there and had given all her money to pay for the first month and that if they did not like it they could band together and give her enough money to move away, otherwise they would just have to deal with it. she also explained that the only real difference between them is their skin colour. the boy then explains that during the time that they lived there the father became ill and the neighbours were as nice as anyone could be.
recalls.12: The mother was explaining that although she has different skin colour, everything else was the same, they were both people. Skin colour doesn't define or make people different.
recalls.13: The couple got out of the police car and the mother faced the waiting crowd of neighbours. She announced that she and her family werre going to stay where they were for at least a month as they had paid the rent and didn't have the money to move again. She told them that they were all the same except for the colour of their skin. She said the only way they would be able to get her family out was to raise the cash needed to move. In the meantime her husband was taken ill.
recalls.14: The police took the mother and boy home in the police wagon as it was easier than listening to the mother . When they got back, the mother came out of the wagon and saw the neighbours all looking out. She told them that they would be there for the whole month as they had already paid a months rent and that they may as well get used to it unless they wanted to give her money to move out. The neighbours turned out to be nice people and supported the family when the father became sick
recalls.15: The neighbours came out of the house because the bell on the patrol was clanging. They got out of the patrol and went down some steps. The mother confronted all of the neighbours and said she was just the same as them in all respects except her colour. That she was just trying to provide for her family, and that she couldn't afford to move so if they wanted her to go, that they would have to give her the money. She told them how much she paid and that she didn't know who had broken the window but that winter was coming and she was afraid of the cold. The narrator reminds us that the experience was frightening.
recalls.16: THE WOMAN COMPLAINED THAT THE SRONES HAD HIT HER HOUSE AND THEY ALL HID IN THE STAIRCASE, THE WOMAN ASKED THE POLICEMAN, WHO WAS BEING PULLED BY A HORSE WHAT SHE SHOULD DO AND HE TOLD HER HE DIDNT KNOW . SHE QUESTIONED WHY HE COULDN'T HELP AND HE SUGGESTED SHE MOVE HOUSE, SHE SAID SHE COULDNT AFFORD IT BECUASE SHE HAD PUT ALL HER MONEY INTO THE HOUSE THEY ARE IN NOW
recalls.17: The police dropped the mother and son at their home in their horse drawn carriage. The carriage had a bell that went 'clang clang clang'. Everyone in the neighbourhood could hear it and came out to see what was happening. The police opened the back door of the carriage to let them out. The mother looked around at the people staring and told them that she had paid to live there a month but was not sure if they would be there longer as she did not have enough money for it. She told them they would have to give them the money if they wanted them to move elsewhere. No one replied. During that time the father got sick. The neighbours were all nicer after that, as much as they could be and that was the introduction to the neighbourhood.
recalls.18: The neighbours responded in a nice way and welcomed them even when there was trouble
recalls.19: The mother and boy got out of the back of the police patrol and the mother spoke to the neighbours telling them they would be there for the month as they could not afford to move. She suggested if they wanted them out of the house they should raise the money between them for a move, they did not do this. The father then became ill and the neighbours were very helpful and did whatever they could.
recalls.20:
The mother stood out the front after exiting the wagon and said loudly, 'we are here, the house was rented to us and we have paid for the month, so we will be here for the month. I don't know if we can afford to pay for another month but we will see. It's winter and it's cold and a stone has been put through the window. If you did this you can make it right by fixing it.' but no one ever did.
The father got sick that month and the neighbours were as nice as anything also seeing off any trouble. But to the boy it still felt terrible from his very first moment in that home.
recalls.21: The mother was clanging before the boy was returned home, that is all I can recall
recalls.22: The mother called out all the neighbors while being dropped back off at their home by the police officer. Telling them if they want her and her family to go away they should pay them because they have no money left after the brutal robbery/stoning their window after their arrival. After a short while the father became ill and the neighbors actually helped out despite the awful racist welcoming they had from all the others because of their skin colour.
recalls.23: The mother spoke to the neighbors and said that they will stay there for a month as they had already paid in advance and cannot afford to move until then. She said if anyone is unhappy with that then they should get together and get the money to pay for them to move, but they obviously didn't do that as everyone was struggling with money. Sometime after it the father got sick and the neighbors were as nice as anyone could of been.
recalls.24: This was our welcoming to the neighbourhood
recalls.25: the wagon had a bell on it and that clang clanged, so the neighbours came out of their houses to see what was going on, when they got out of the back of the horse and wagon, the mother told all the people how much she had paid to be there and that they were paid up for the month but she did not know about the month after that. she had no more money and was not going to move and she did not have new window money, she was there for the month whether they liked it or not.If they objected to them being there then they could give her money to move on , but without it she was staying. no one gave her any money but did leave them alone, when his father got sick they did help out just as any other neighbours would
recalls.26: The police patrol had a bell that clanged, and all of the neighbours came out to see what was going on. They came through the back of the police patrol. The mother stood in front of the neighbours and told them that they were going to be there for a month, that they had paid the rent upfront for a month and she couldn't afford to move. If they wanted her to move then they would have to all gather up their money and pay for them to move somewhere else. They didn't have any money though. She said they would have to accept that they would be there for a month. And that she couldn't afford new windows. That they were different, but ultimately the same. Her husband got sick and the neighbours responded as though it was anyone else
recalls.27: When the police returned the mother and the boy home, she informed them of how much money she spent renting the house and that she doesn't have any money to fix broken windows nor rent another house. So she said, if they do not want me in that house, they should have at least said it. She then asked them to give her some of the money she used in paying for the rent so that she can find somewhere else to rent, but they also did not have any money to give to her. From there, the boy and his mother were taken to his father who was also sick.
recalls.28: The mother confronted the neighbours and said that although she was not the same skin colour as them, she was similar to them and was just trying to feed her family just like them. It seemed to work with the neighbours.
recalls.29: The police brought the mother and her son home. The drawn horse police carriage had a bell that clanged and that caused all the neighbors to come out to see what was happening. Once they got home the mother spoke out to all the neighbors that they are paid up for the month. She told them how much it was and how much they had. They can't afford for move so they are stuck with them for the month. They also can't be affording any more broken windows. Now they don't know if they will still be there for the next month but if they don't want them there then the neighbors should get a collection going to help pay them to move out. Of course they didn't. She told them that she may look different from them (skin color) but she is the same as them. They did end up staying and the neighbors did become more neighborly. Eventually the father did get sick and the neighbors did help out. And this was their welcome into their new neighborhood.
recalls.30: They told that they were saying for a month, they didnt know if they were going to Stay more than a month but at least a month they were saying , and she told them if they want them out they needed to gave them money to move out, and they didnt do that . In the meantime the father got sick and everyone were nice to them , but the welcoming was terrifiying
recalls.31: On arriving back at the house , the mother explained to the mob of people outside that she was aware that they didn’t want us to be in that house because of our colour but that she couldn’t afford to move anywhere else. If they wanted us out then they could pay for us to move, but they were probably just as poor as us. It was a frightening time but it became clear that the neighbours were just like us and were very helpful when dad became ill.
recalls.32: Basically, the police , when they arrived, they made a noise because it was 1925 and it was a horse-drawn wagon with bells on, which caused a commotion, and brought out all the neighbours to their doors. The mother was a proud and dignified woman and told those in the neighborhood (who were mostly Jewish, even though the officer said they were Irish), that she would not move as she only had a month's rent, which she had paid and could not afford to move. It appears that she didn't have the money to pay after that either. She told her neighbours, who were being racist by throwing stones at her window, that if they wanted her to move they would have to pay for it themselves, which they didn't do. They were poor themselves, perhaps they were a bit ashamed, but in case, for the remainder of the time they lived there they were good neighbours and even checked in when the father fell ill. The narrator, who was a boy at the time, finishes by saying that this was their introduction to the neighbourhood, which wasn't the best.
recalls.33: The police said if we wanted anything to change, we would need to move. My mother explained that we would need to stay, as we had no money after the move, given it had just happened. We explained to the neighbours that if they wanted us to not live in their neighbourhood, they would have to pay, however they didn't do so - likely, they had no money of their own. During the time we lived there, my father became sick, and when this happened our neighbours were very kind and supportive. It was a scary welcoming to the neighbourhood.

The police patrol arrived at their home and all the neighbours were stood around watching. recalls.69:
After the police returned the mother and the boy home in the police wagon, a crowd of neighbors gathered to watch. The mother confronted them, saying she didn't understand why they were hostile. She acknowledged their differences in skin color but emphasized that she was just trying to provide for her family. She explained that they had rented the house, paid a month's rent, and had no money to move. She told the crowd that if they wanted her to leave, they would need to raise the money for her to relocate, as she couldn't afford to replace broken windows or move.

The neighbours did not offer any money, and the family stayed. Although their initial reception was hostile and frightening, with time, the neighbours became kinder, especially when the father fell ill. Despite this eventual goodwill, the speaker recalls the fear and tension of their difficult introduction to the neighbourhood.

recalls.71:
The police were returning the mother and the boy back to their home in a horse drawn wagon. The cart had a large bell on it that let off a loud 'clang' sound as they went. The noise from the bell caused a lot of people from the neighbourhood to come out into the street to see what was going on.

When they got home the mother addressed the crowd of neighbours before the police wagon had the opportunity to leave. She told them that aside from the colour of their skin, her family was just the same as theirs. She said that she had rented the house, that she had paid for a month up front, and that she had no more money to move. She said that even though it was cold, she had no more money to fix the windows, and that if they truly didn't want her and her family to live there, they could give her enough money to move somewhere else, because otherwise they would be there at least for the month. The boy recounted that after that day, for the duration of their tenancy, the neighbours were nice to their family, including when his father got sick.

recalls.79:
The police took the mom and boy home in the the police patrol, which made a clang, clang, clang sound, similar to the clang of a trolley. The patrol was long, with a door at the back. When they reached home, a crowd was gathered. The man, the police officer, climbed off his horse, went to the back of the patrol, and opened the door for us. My mother addressed the crowd, saying she didn't know why they'd stoned the house and broken the window. She said they'd used all the money they had to pay for one month's rent, and unless the people gathered wanted to pay for the family to move, they would be staying for the month. After that, she didn't know what would happen. She said they were no different than anyone else here.
During the following month, the boy's father was ill, and the neighbours treated the family with kindness, helping them with food, etc.
That was the family's experience during the month of living in this place, a Black family in an Irish neighbourhood, dealing with Irish police.

recalls.81:
The mother insisted that the police escort her and her son back home on Third and Wharton via the police cart and horse. The police cart had a bell which was rung, making a loud clanging noise that attracted the neighbourhood, who all came out to see what was going on. As the mother got out of the vehicle, she defiantly addressed the crowd. She stated that although the colour of her skin was different, she was just the same as the people living in the neighbourhood. She simply wanted to provide a home for her family, and that she had given all of her money to pay for the rent for one month. This meant that she would not be going anywhere for the next month, and she was working hard to earn more money as she was unsure if she would have enough to continue paying the rent. She then referred to the accident when there was a group of people who were throwing stones through the window, which scared the boy and the siblings. 

After the incident, the boy's father got sick and the neighbourhood rallied around the family, offering to provide help where they could, and to stop any troublemakers causing harm to the family. The boy refers to the first time that they moved to the area as a terrifying and frightening time.
recalls.82: In this episode, a family is taken home by a police patrol after a troubling incident. The narrator vividly describes the sound of the patrol’s bell—“clang clang clang”—as it approaches. Neighbors gather, curious about the commotion. The mother bravely confronts the crowd, expressing her frustration and asserting her humanity despite their racial differences. She explains that she’s rented the house for a month, emphasizing her struggle to provide for her family during the cold winter, and challenges the neighbors to help if they don’t want her there. Her determination shines through, highlighting both vulnerability and resilience in the face of prejudice.

recalls.93: After the mother and the boy were returned home, the mother saw all the neighbors standing there watching her. She told them all how much she had paid in rent for the month and told them that they were at least staying there a month.  She said she didn’t know if they would have enough money to live there next month.  If the neighbors didn’t want her living there, then they could give her enough money to move again, but none of them gave her any money. It was during this time that the father got sick however, the neighbors where is nice has anyone else would be
recalls.94: When police returned the mother and boy home home in convoy. They talked with the neighbors and told them that they do not have enough money to move out and how much money spent renting this house. If neighbors want them to move then gather some money and give it to mother and boy so that they can move out. Eventually everything settled up. Boy's father became ill, and neighbors were supporting.
recalls.95: when they returned home the people got out their houses to see what was going on and when the mother got off the carriage she said out loud so they can all hear " why you're going this to me I don't know and I don't have money to move out because I just moved here, so if you don't want me here you can all put money together to help  me move to another place, and I don't have the money to buy new windows that you just broke" they didn't give here the money because they also did not have the money. they stayed there for a while and the father fell ill and the neighbors were nice.
recalls.96: The mother berated them saying she was the same for them trying to provide for her family and couldn't afford to move. If they wanted her to move they would have to give her money becuase she could afford it.  The neighbours were nice when the father became ill
recalls.97: After the police returned the mother and the boy home, as the mother got out the police patrol and everyone came out to see what was happening due to the clang of the bell, she explained that she had paid rent for a month. therefore, she was going to stay there for that month and did not know if she would have enough money to stay longer. She mentioned it was winter and could no afford to fix the window and would have to cold enter her house. She asked for whoever broke it to fix it but no one did. She also explained that besides her color, she was no different from the people who lived there. she also said if they did not want her there, they should come together and pitch in with money so that she could afford to rent another house in a different place but that also did not happen. the little boy said that whole situation sacred him.
recalls.98: The neighbours heard the bell and horses of the police as they approached the mother’s house.  The mother addressed the neighbours by saying why have they done this to her,  because apart from her colour they were the same, just trying to provide a home for her family.  She explained that they paid a months rent for this house and if they wanted her to move they would have to pay her some money,  so she could do that. She said that she didn't have any money to move, so they would have to stay there. Her husband who was a drinker became sick and the neighbours were nice and helped them.  Too be honest rather confused with the timeline as to when that happened!
recalls.99: The police took them home and the mother confronted the neighbours. She told them that they could either raaise enough money for them to move or leave them alone. By standing up to them she gained their respect and they became supportive of the family.

recall_scores_completions.6075e12159e69162ee283711:
Alternative version of the story:

We relocated to Third and Wharton. My father, who had a drinking problem, helped move the furniture before leaving to return the horses. My mother went to the market to buy food. I was left alone with my siblings when a stone came crashing through the window. I quickly moved the kids to the stairway for safety and went out to find my mother. I was terrified but I prayed and ran to Fourth street where my mother was shopping. I found her and tried to explain what happened when a policeman approached us. He told us that the neighborhood was bad and suggested we move. My mother refused, stating that we had just moved in and had no money to move again. She confronted the policeman about his duty to protect us but he claimed he couldn't do anything. My mother decided to go to the police station to seek help. She spoke to the captain who also suggested we move. My mother insisted that we couldn't move and demanded that the police take us home. We were taken home in a police patrol and my mother addressed the neighbors, explaining our situation and stating that we would be staying for at least a month. During our stay, my father fell ill but the neighbors were surprisingly helpful. It was a terrifying welcome to the neighborhood.

1. **When the police returned the mother and the boy home** - Adverbial clause indicating the time of the main action.
2. **they went in a carriage** - Main clause describing the action of the police, the mother, and the boy.
3. **that had a bell** - Relative clause modifying "carriage."
4. **that went "clang, clang, clang"** - Relative clause modifying "bell."
5. **which attracted the attention of the neighbours** - Relative clause modifying the entire preceding clause about the bell sound.
6. **who came out to see what was going on** - Relative clause modifying "neighbours."
7. **When they got out of the police patrol carriage** - Adverbial clause indicating the time of the subsequent action.
8. **the mother turned to the neighbours** - Main clause describing the mother’s action.
9. **She told them that** - Main clause indicating the action of speaking.
10. **apart from their skin colour, her family was the same as theirs** - Noun clause acting as the object of "told."
11. **and explained that** - Coordinating conjunction with a new main clause indicating another action of speaking.
12. **even if they have a problem with her being there** - Conditional adverbial clause within the explained matter.
13. **she paid all her money in rent that month** - Result clause linked to the condition.
14. **so will be staying for at least a month** - Consequence clause related to the payment of rent.
15. **unless they want to raise the money to fund her move** - Conditional clause modifying the consequence of "will be staying."
16. **She also told them** - Main clause indicating a continued action of speaking.
17. **it was cold,** - Independent clause within the direct speech.
18. **it was winter,** - Coordinated clause within the direct speech.
19. **and they could not afford new windows** - Coordinated clause within the direct speech explaining their situation concerning the cold and winter conditions.
